Articles.Content:
Something to think about when you are looking at all the derelict objects in your Kerbal universe - Vanguard 1 and the upper stage rocket used to launch the satellite, are still in orbit. And will be until somewhere around 2200 A.D. Vanguard 1 was launched on March 17, 1958. About a year and a half from now, it will have been in orbit for 60 years. Vanguard 2 and Vanguard 3 are still in orbit too for that matter. In fact two pieces of the upper stage of Vanguard 3 are still in orbit along with the satellite.


NEO (Near Earth Object) J002E3 was at first believed to be an asteroid, but has since been tentatively identified as the S-IVB third stage of the Apollo 12 Saturn V rocket launched in November 1969.
It's pretty crazy to think that you could make a museum from all the junk we've got floating in orbit. Most geostationary satellites won't fall back to Earth for thousands of years.

This graph is an eye-opener.

It was the fundamental part of answer to my question "can one use a solar sail to prevent orbital decay?" - smart angling/folding the sail technically could serve to accelerate a satellite in orbit, but the break-even altitude where solar pressure overcomes atmospheric drag is 1000km. And at that altitude... you don't need orbit decay counter-measures.

Edited October 3, 2016 by Sharpy
Thankfully Ed White's glove from Gemini 4 has come down, imagine finding out your million dollar's worth of satellite was destroyed because an astronaut threw a punch at it in 1965.

Knowing early astronauts, he was probably hoping it would hit a sat, cause it's a good bar story.

On October 3, 2016 at 3:03 AM, Choctofliatrio2.0 said:

It's pretty crazy to think that you could make a museum from all the junk we've got floating in orbit. Most geostationary satellites won't fall back to Earth for thousands of years.

Hopefully we will.  Probably not.

I used to have a book that cataloged all the objects in orbit (as of 1965 or there abouts).  Along with orbital elements and other data was a column for reentry or predicted decay.  There were many that were in the decades and more in the 100s of years, but at least a few said 1,000,000+ years.

Wish I could remember any of them...

 

(Pretty sure it was an early copy of "The RAE Table of Earth Satellites"

Edited October 4, 2016 by tg626
This forum sucks on mobile...

It's pretty crazy to think that you could make a museum from all the junk we've got floating in orbit.
